I hope you enjoy this video. My thought was to not make a "YouTube video" style video.... but to make something I would be proud of for years to come. About a year ago I was presented with an opportunity to go to a sea turtle conservation center in Costa Rica. There I met Valerie, an amazing conservation researcher who has a true passion for sea turtles. When I returned home I contacted Dr. Christine Finniger who taught me more. When the Cook Museum told me about their amazing opportunity with Kale the endangered Kemp's Ridley sea turtle, I was totally floored. I hope you enjoy this video as much as I enjoyed the experience.

Also, this is the first time DJI has sponsored Smarter Every Day. The Mavic Mini is going to be a great tool for upcoming videos. I've already shot a couple of things for upcoming videos with it. If you'd like to signal to them that you're glad they've decided to sponsor Smarter Every Day it would be awesome if you'd consider going here: →https://bit.ly/3ePEAjS ← and use promo code KLDE2Q87JZU9
to get 5% off when purchasing the DJI Mavic Mini or Mavic Mini Fly More Combo. They didn't tell me to put this in the comment section. I legitimately like the product and think you will too!

As always, thanks for watching and supporting my efforts to learn all kinds of interesting things. I'm grateful for you.
Regards,
Destin

I live on Long Island New York and when I was younger I used to volunteer to walk the beach of the north shore of the island because Kemps Ridleys used to and still do get stuck on the north side of the island and can't find their way back south.  So we were KR turtle 🐢 rescue volunteers 🙋‍♂️.  We have a facility in Riverhead New York to recover injured and trapped KR turtles 🐢.  It was a great experience 👍 😀!!

I almost wasn’t going to watch this when I randomly came across it in my search, but I’m definitely glad I did!! It was VERY well put together and sure educational!
The one reason why I started my search on sea turtles a while ago WAS because I came across the dr with the sea turtle with the straw in his nose. I’ve always wondered what happened to them since and I’m glad to hear that they were spotted doing well 2 yrs later! I was also rooting for that baby sea turtle at the start line and it brought tears to my eyes to see them finally get up and flop away! This video had me laughing, crying and I awe the whole time and even when I had to pause it to carry on with my day, it left me wondering how it was going to end because it sucked me in that much! On top of this being one of my favorite topics, you have a way of sucking the audience in and idk what your other videos are like, but I hope they’re all as good as this one because you nailed it! It looks like A LOT of work went into it all especially with all that traveling to make it happen! Thank you for that and showing more of the behind the scenes of all the hard work that goes into saving all of these precious creatures!! And a HUGE thank you to all of those who do the work they do because it definitely makes a difference even if it saves only a few of them here and there! It’s nice to see how everyone really is rooting for these animals and definitely has me contemplating also doing the same as a career because even though I’m sure it’s not easy work, it definitely looks like it has so many rewards and I’ve never been so emotional over just watching the same topic all on video (except for when I initially did see that straw sea turtle video-that one definitely was the one that first pulled me in!!), I couldn’t imagine actually doing this hands on and how wonderful that would be!! I can’t wait to check out the resources you mentioned to learn more!
Thank you again for all of this!!!

My first encounter with sea turtles was as a teenager when I went to Europe as a student ambassador. We weren’t to a sea turtle rescue in Greece and it was amazing. My second encounter was when I saw the biggest turtle I’d ever seen while deep sea fishing with my dad, grandpa, and brother. It was massive, majestic, and just awe inspiring. In fact the captain of our boat said it was much larger than even the largest he’d seen and he’d been on the water for 60+ years. He was even stricken by emotion. It was just this massive majestic creature, floating atop the surface, during sunset. It was gorgeous. I instantly wished I was able to see even moment of its life through its perspective. All the places it’s been. All the different things it’d seen.

That was a correct decision to call Kale non-releasable... I have a perineal version of the exact same thing, and after 3 surgeries it still gives me problems that wouldn't be livable without human medical intervention. He would have been in so much pain for years before finally getting into a very slow death from all kinds of trouble just like that lady described. In fact, in his scenario, the "happiest" end in the wild would be to get hit by a boat propeller. The second would be sepsis (which is a horrible death). I hope they will keep doing that flushing consistently and that he'll live on to inspire more people to be aware of the fragile but indispensable marine biosphere...

I'm not sure if 100% hatching and releasing is actually doing good for the population in the long run. Because it will enable gene sets that were discarded by nature to procreate, and occupy eggs that otherwise would have been fertilized by a more suitable male with a stronger set of genes... Reducing beach predation and human disturbance: YES! That is definitely helping a lot. Because those factors are not dependent on the health of genes. Science exists..only a fool would deny this..yet people live in defiance of scientific proofs everyday throughout their lives to their own harm. It becomes the responsibility of the scientist then to assume the role of simultaneously getting in everyone’s face up close and uncomfortably and then pry our minds open and force volumes of information into them in an impossibly irresistible and entertaining way. We have to deny our natural impulses to be solely self-serving and egocentric and it becomes the scientists primary mission to make us WANT to! Against our natural desire to resist that which causes us to accept limitations to that which serves our every desire, you the scientist must present science in such a way that we unwittingly put aside our infinitesimally tiny attention span and delay our own gratification without being forcefully legislated or compelled to do so simply because we are interested.
Science bears the brunt of our ignorance..it always has..and only those scientists who increase our understanding without diminishing our ability to remain prosperous by enriching our desire to better our future prospects of success in a way that pleases us and strokes our ego will not be frustrated and discouraged by our innate ignorance...the state in which we are most comfortable. I was in Cancun many years ago and it happened to be when a big sea turtle hatch was happening. There were almost no tourists at that time and we were the only people on the beach for days. Hundreds of baby turtles were being picked off by frigate birds left and right.  We fought the birds off all day but weren't very effective.  We decided to get buckets and put as many as we could into them and keep them safe until dark.  Then we took them out to the edge of the surf and released them.  They all did well and swam away,  I'd estimate we released a few hundred babies that night.  I don't know if we did a good thing or broke laws or what, but the babies didn't stand a chance with the birds.  Hopefully we did the right thing.

“Knowing that the lifespan of each of these turtles could be 50 years, but in order for that to start they had to make it to the water.”
These are some powerful words. You’re saying that turtles have a similar lifespan to us humans, but taking this and applying it to how we live our lives we may extrapolate that often in fear of failure, scared to “make it to the water.” We’re all really just little baby sea turtles who face a beach front everyday. We face the decision to get into the water and try something that can change us in a positive way. We just need to overcome the fear and have the guts for survival, have the willingness to sacrifice who we are now for what we can be tomorrow.

Every year I go to a Florida key with my whole family, and we stay in the same hotel. The beaches are always littered with nests while we're there, and almost every year we get to see them hatch, and sometimes even see the mothers lay their eggs. About three days ago, on my last day of vacation, I along with some family members went to check for turtles, like we had every night. We hadn't seen any for the whole trip, and this was just a last try sort of thing. We were walking along the beach for a few minutes, and then - a few feet in front of me I saw a little baby turtle sliding his way towards the ocean. We went up the beach, found the nest, and tried to be as careful as we could to not harm their journey to the ocean, while still protecting them until they hit the surf. It was amazing. I was able to watch them come up, out of the nest, and follow them all the way to the ocean. It never gets old.

When first hatched the hatchlings have a burst of energy once they get to the top of the nest and then sprint to the ocean. By removing them from the natural nest and keeping them in buckets they waste that energy and exhaust it in the bucket. It is best to mark the nests and wait for the hatchling to  reach the surface themselves. once they have all left the nest dig it out carefully by hand to check for stragglers and rescue those from the nest and bring them down to the shore in buckets.
Laminar flow is over rated. Turbulent flow is where it is at. Chaos at its most primal.

To bring in more of your own expertise, you should work with more ecologists/conservation biologists on how math and statistics is applied to conservation. There are a lot of relatively simple math concepts that are widely used in conservation, and it could not only help to introduce people to conservation and inspire them, but it actually makes math more interesting and fun to learn when you can see how it's used. As a starting point, (capture) mark recapture would be a great example of simple math and probability and how it's used to estimate and monitor population sizes. As an introduction, you can use it to "count" or estimate the number of marbles (or jellybeans) in a container. Then maybe do your own experiment of capturing something, marking it, and then resighting/capturing later (maybe with some kind of bug in your yard? set out some non-lethal traps, paint a dot on them, then release them, the trap again later). It's nice to see someone like you, (bright and articulate), suddenly being enthralled by one of the many creatures of the sea, and sharing your excitement and wonder with others who also may be unaware of the incredible diversity of life in our oceans. I have been diving the oceans of the world since 1962 and will continue to until I just can't do it anymore. I have never gotten over the excitement of seeing the richness and beauty of life underwater that continues to thrive despite man's efforts to destroy it.
If you were captivated by the sight of one sea turtle in Hawaii, get certified in a real SCUBA course (not one of those resort or cruise ship 1 or 2 day courses), do some easy diving for a while in the Caribbean, (Turks and Caicos, the Cayman Islands, Belize, Costa Rica for example, to get some experience, and then go to places like Palau, Micronesia, Fiji, Papau New Guinea, the Soloman Islands, the Sea of Cortez, and Indonesia (Raja Ampat).
I guarantee you will never regret expanding your world to include the oceans. You may also eliminate certain protein from your diet, although I confess that sushi and sashimi are still my favorite foods. Didn't try fugu when I was in Japan last year. Maybe next time.

Temperature determinant sexing is pretty common in many reptiles. When breeding for the pet trade, breeders will vary the temperature of the incubating eggs to produce males or females, either for the pet itself, since males or females can have different behavioral or physical traits that make them better pets, or to maximize any future breeding options, since males can produce many more offspring per year than females.

I had an amazing experience with baby sea turtles once.
I was in Mexico on a honeymoon and while on a driving excursion we stopped at a restaurant off the beach. We had about 15 minutes to walk around before we were had to set off again. Was only about 10-20 people on the beach when all of a sudden we heard a lot of commotion and heard something along the lines of "stop!" and I looked down to see baby sea turtles coming up from the group in every direction.
There was an unknown nest (the area of the beach is very remote and low traffic) and people were moving tables and chairs to give them room. Everyone was very respectful and didn't pick them up. If you stood still they would go around you or over your feet. A lot of us went to the water and watched as they hit the water and took off like a bullet.
Was so unexpected and something we will never forget.

I spent my grade school years living in Mexico, in the late 1950s and early 1960s. My father, an exec with an American company that was expanding into Latin America, was a real edge dweller. He drove us (Mom and 4 kids) all over Mexico to places no Gringo had ever been. One trip included some boating, I believe somewhere off of Yucatan. We came upon a very large pen built in the ocean for collection of massive adult sea turtles. The 4 of us kids jumped out of the boat, swam over and climbed into the pen. I mounted a turtle, like one would mount a horse, and secured myself using my hands on the edge of the turtle's shell at its neck. It took me for a ride I will never forget. SO FAST, diving down into the water. An unforgettable ride for a 7 year old girl. I've thought with great sadness over the years, many times, about those turtles, and all the others that must have been caught and sold.

Sure we'd be looked after, but I wonder if that sheltered  (long) life in a tightly contained space is all that good and preferable to one with a lot more risk, but also freedom and the ability to move and live the way you were born to. Alas, I'm no turtle mind reader, but it is some food for thought.

Sea turtles causes have forever been ruined for me by one woman. One year when we were staying one the beach in the Florida gulf near where some sea turtles had laid eggs. One day when my dad was walking about 10 yds from the marked area one of the sea turtle conservation people yelled at him and threatened to have him fined for attempting to disturb a sea turtle nest. Late in the week we were lucky enough to be there when one of the nests was hatching. I was watching it while my cousins (7 and 9 at the time) and they decided to take pictures with their parents phones, without realizing it they had the flash on (which I guess can disorientate the turtles) the same woman that yelled at my dad came up to my cousins and started yelling at them and cussing them out. I stepped in, toile the phones and apologized to her, she wasn’t having any of it and stared cussing me out (I was like 13 at the time), she ended up calling the local game warden trying to press charges against me and my cousins, luckily there were several independent witnesses around that backed me up about how crazy she was being so the game warden was just kind of annoyed by the woman wasting his time. Some of the witnesses called the local office of the  international national organization she was associated with that night to complain and my parents and aunt/uncle did the same thing the next day. The people basically told us that they didn’t believe the woman had done anything wrong, even after she told us exactly what happened (i.e the woman told the truth about what happened when she reported back to her bosses) and said they may file federal charges against me and my cousins. We then emailed the international headquarters of the organization and they basically told us the same thing. After that my cousins didn’t go back down to the beach for the rest of the week and they’re still not interested in going to the beach 6 years later.

In general, I'm not a fan of zoos and aquariums. When making money off of animals, it can be all too easy to stuff too many animals into a space and not care well for them. Some are nothing more than farms that charge admission and try to appear as if they are doing good by the animals in their care.
But for situations like Kale's, I am glad that there are reputable places to care for the animals that can't go back home. He/she seems to be happy being able to have a semblance of the life they had in the wild. And I'm glad for place that save animals like him, and the community that works with them, that otherwise would have suffered and died from injuries in the wild.
I hope more people will stop and think about the effect that we have on the world around us. In our carnivorous, disposable world, we cause so much harm that we never stop to notice.

I have four amateur theories in regards to Kale's preference for that seemingly uncomfortable position in its transportation bucket.
1. The position allowed Kale to see more than just the grey walls of the bucket, which might feel less threatening. A year rehabilitating in a tank may have taught Kale that the only way out is up, when, in the open water, the way out is in any direction it chooses.
2. Frequent treatments of the fistula may have desensitized Kale to that position, or maybe created a survival instinct within Kale that associated that position with positive outcomes.
3. Lying flat to the bottom with no water buoyancy could be an irritant to the fistula or internal scar tissue and that position could take pressure off the injury.
4. The forces from acceleration and deceleration of the vehicle might be reminiscent of waves and it might prefer aligning its anteroposterior(?) axis accordingly. A 90° turn of the bucket could test this theory.

Hi Destin,
When I was in high school, it was a tradition for about 20 students to go on a "turtle trip" to La Gloria Beach in remote Mexico from middle of nowhere Idaho to work with a biologist doing the same work as shown in the first 14 minutes of this video. Since I went in 2013 and 2014, that part of Mexico has been classified as unsafe to travel and with that, the annual Turtle Trips have been cancelled. Normally, biology interested students will go out for 10-15 days a year in September and volunteer their time to work with a turtle biologist in the field. I was lucky enough to go twice, and students worked their butts off for years to save enough money to go on this trip. What an amazing experience this was and it inspired me to get my marine biology degree. My question is, do you know if this biologist (or any others for that matter) do work like that or if they may be interested? Is there a place I can find contact information for the researchers in Costa Rica? Thank you so much for posting this content. It is so important for the future of all turtle species.

So my random sea turtle story is only amazing due to the complete randomness and extremely low odds of occurrence. Here goes: I live in Floridax and offshore fishing is something that my family does a lot of. About 10 years ago I was going out fishing with my brother. We were going tuna fishing which is usually about 80-100 miles off the east coast. We typically run hard out to about the 70 mile mark, and from there slow down a bit while we are getting rods and gear ready, and start looking for weed lines, birds, etc.  I just happen to be sitting on the edge of the gunnel looking into the water when I see a patch of seaweed about the size of a basketball. On top of its was a sea turtle about the size of a golf ball. We didn't disturb him, it looked like he was just resting, but was well alive and moving around. And that's my completely random sea turtle story for the day. 70-75 miles away from anything and happen to find something the size of a golf ball that I wasn't looking for.

One of my favorite memories from being younger is the loggerhead turtles in conincidentally Destin, FL... A few times we vacationed when they were laying their eggs.. Actually happened across some researchers who were explaining what was going on and why and taking blood samples. The momma turtles basically go into a trance when they start their nest.. and are sensitive to white light, but less so to red light. At least two other times we were there when the eggs were hatching. Once at night - someone was standing in the surf with a huge coleman lantern because there was no moon - and once during the day. During the day, it must have been a dozen of us that protected the baby turtles from predators while they made their way to the water.. And after the first group I spend hours digging out the remainder of the next, freeing the little guys who couldn't make it on their own. To this day I like to think that just maybe one of the turtles I saved ended up making it.. ended up breeding.. just might be responsible for thousands and thousands of other turtles by now. Turtles are pretty cool.

When I was a wee lad, my family and I were on vacation and stayed at the beach until sunset and even after dark, hoping to see some bioluminescent jelly fish. Instead what we found were dozens of baby sea turtles hatching before our eyes in a several shallow depressions.

Of course around half of them were mesmerized by the lights of the nearby highway and started ponderously approaching in that direction which was inevitable death for such small, cute, harmless little things.

So we spent about a good hour re-orienting the waywards back to the sandy surf and into the big blue ocean. I'd like to think those sea turtles we saved are still out there, thriving to this very day.
